instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS IS PPBUS_G3H voltage after it has passed through a current sense resistor that supplies the TPS51980 and its associated buck converter with voltage to create the PP5V_S4 power rail..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Does not turn on or charge
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

-Green light on charger but then turns into Orange Light
-No boot, no fan spin

-Not sure of what each rail does yet as I’m pretty new to this
-Also not sure of the different “states” like S0, S3, S5, etc.
-So I went to the schematics and measured a handful of rails and I’m hoping someone can point me in the right direction. 


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>[U]                                          [/U]- 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>[U]     [/U]- 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL>[U]                    [/U]- 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V3_ISNS</SIGNAL>[U]         [/U]- 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER5V_ISNS</SIGNAL>[U]           [/U]- 12.58V

<SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_CONN_R</SIGNAL>[U]            [/U]- 16.4V    (should be 20V)
<SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL>[U]                  [/U]- 16.6V    (should be 20V) 

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>[U]                               [/U]- 3.4V    
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_SMC_SPVSR</SIGNAL>[U]        [/U]- 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>[U]                              [/U]- 2.58V    (should be 3.42)

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>[U]                          [/U]- 0.9V    (should be 5V)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>[U]                         [/U]- 0V        (should be 5V)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>[U]                         [/U]- 0V        (should be 5V)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>[U]                         [/U]- 0V        (should be 5V)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>[U]                     [/U]- 2.5V    (should be 3.3)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>[U]                     [/U]- 0V        (should be 3.3)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>[U]                  [/U]- 2.58V    (should be 3.3)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>[U]                     [/U]- 0V        (should be 3.3)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>[U]                     [/U]- 0V        (should be 3.3)


thanks in advance for any help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Does not turn on or charge
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> - 16.6V (should be 20V)"
Do NOT make wrong assumptions so easy!
I bet you are not using 85W charger and this is a good reason the board doesn't turn on.
Test with original charger and report back.

BTW, do not make so many measurements in the same power rail; names change a bit, still the same rail in fact.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Does not turn on or charge
threads.message:
Hi and thanks for responding! 

I was not making assumptions, sorry. I was just listing what the schematic said. Trying to be thorough with the info I provided.
Thanks for the measurement tip too, like I said, a little new to this, so I wasn't 100% sure if the rails were related. I thought they might be, but wanted to be thorough. 

The charger is an 85W actually. (which is what my friend told me was the original when he asked me to look at his computer lol)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Does not turn on or charge
threads.message:
60W charger (I happen to have one laying around. not sure if this the original type. I do have a DPS I can hook up if you think it will help)



<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>                    - 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>     - 12.58V   

<SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL>     - 16.5V   
  
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>               - 3.4V    
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>               - 3.4V  
  
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>              - 0.9V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>            - 1.28V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>            - 0V    
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>         - 0V    
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>            - 0V    
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>            - 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Does not turn on or charge
threads.message:
This board requires 85W charger.
It will not turn on with 45/60W charger alone; unless battery is connected and has some charge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Does not turn on or charge
threads.message: oh I'm sorry I misread your original comment, the original measurements are from an 85W charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  Does not turn on or charge
threads.message:
Post basic voltages of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> chip; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.
Also check diode mode to ground at all big coils.
